intro: Tapinanthus brunneus, commonly known as the parasitic morning glory, is a hemiparasitic plant that attaches to the roots of other plants to obtain water and nutrients. It is native to Africa and belongs to the Convolvulaceae family, which includes many flowering plants. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers and has heart-shaped leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. It thrives in moist, shaded environments and is often found in woodland areas. Due to its parasitic nature, it can negatively impact the growth of its host plants.
